video_description:
The ASUS EP121 is a powerful new (2011) Tablet PC running windows7. The  EP121 takes advantage of Windows 7 multi-touch, a Wacom Active Digitizer  and an Intel Core i5 processor to deliver a powerful and flexible tablet experience. 

In Part Two of this video we look at the hardware of the EP121 and the amazing features of Windows 7 that it allows you to take advantage of.

For more information: http://www.tabletpc.com.au/product/3732/45320/asus-eee-slate-ep121-tablet-pc
title: ASUS EP121 Eee Slate Windows 7 Tablet PC - Part 2 - Hardware Review

comments.text: Awesome (asides from battery life)﻿
comments.author: thesivraj

comments.text: great Review!﻿
comments.author: Juan Manuel Espinoza Castillo

comments.text: Great job﻿ as usual.
comments.author: wingzofsteel

comments.text: Very informative﻿ video. I finally got my Asus EP121. I noticed that in your video, you used stylus pen to write and your fingers for windows gestures (like scrolling the doc up and down). But on my EP121, when I write using stylus (say on OneNote) my hand/palm also writes on the screen. This is interfering my writing with stylus. And I cannot use my fingers to scroll like you showed. How can I disable writing with hand/finger/palm while I am writing with stylus?
comments.author: rabs003

comments.text:
Further to my previous question, I know I can disable hand gesture and writing through control panel. But that is bit time consuming as I need to enable and disable﻿ every time. 

All I want is to write with Stylus with out my palm scrabbling rubbish on the screen and at the same time be able to use fingers to make gesture commands.
comments.author: rabs003

comments.text: Thank you so much for this video. But what I'd really like to see is how long the battery will actually last, what starting up is like, how it can handle gaming (I know there are some vids about that, but I miss professionals in them).You know, the things you'd want to know when you're actually thinking of buying one of these. Also I would like to see you put some hardware in it ('foreign' Keyboards, mouses etc) and see how it﻿ handles that. And would you actually have me buy it instead of an pc?
comments.author: guitarrockseverybody

comments.text: Best tablet reviews around. Could you please elaborate as to whether there﻿ is input lag during inking?
comments.author: Suhayb Hafiz

comments.text: Not﻿ for 99% of applications. If you use a heavy duty complicated brush in photoshop you might find some lag. Applications that are well written do not lag at all.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text:
Yes, you could buy it instead of a PC, although personally I would prefer it to have a docking station for that purpose. 

Really battery use time is about 3 - 3.5 hours (they claim up to 4.5 which is possible, but not realistic) and boot up time for a clean PC is quick enough﻿ to be not worth worrying about since you should only need to do it once every few weeks (use standby or hibernate).
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: check for an option in the Wacom "touch settings" tool (search for touch in the windows 7 start menu). You may have a touch / pen abritation option... I do on my Motion J3500 (Wacom Touch / Pen) and it allows a double tap mode where touch is off until I double tap with my finger. I don't have an EP121 to verify if that is an option in their driver implementation. Let me know... BTW, touch is off when the pen is in proximimity with the screen,﻿ but yes it can still be problematic.
comments.author: oztabletpc
guitarrockseverybody

comments.text: Where can I go in Melbourne that﻿ has these (and other tablets) to have a look at first hand?
comments.author: magrpe

comments.text: 12" is great, but makes it a bit heavier and power hungry than it could be. Yes it does come with Active Digitiser Pen and keyboard. Sorry, but can't do Photoshop or gaming video﻿ as I don't do either.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: I would love﻿ it
comments.author: MrVercettti

comments.text:
Thanks for your reply. I could not find that option in EP121. But as you said touch is off when the pen is in proximity, I hadn't realized that before. I just have to be careful to bring pen first to the screen.
I have a new problem now. EP121 comes with mini-hdmi output, but the projectors we have here have only vga input. Now my problem is how to connect mini-hdmi tablet to the projector with only vga. I ignorantly bought a cable from ebay from hdmi to vga but it doesnt work. any solution?﻿
comments.author: rabs003

comments.text: I'm not sure how all that HDMI conversion stuff works... I do have DVI to﻿ HDMI conversion working well on my HTPC, but I have not tried it the other way around. Let us know if you find a solution.

woooooow !!!!﻿

comments.text: I'm﻿ a freshman college student for the up coming fall, and I am looking for a tablet pc such as this one so I can easily take notes, write papers, and do research on the internet, along with everyday stuff. I love this machine but I have a budget and it is a little out of it... I love the way it takes notes as you show and that its durable. Do you know of anything similar to this but might be in my price range, I'm looking at $200-$850.

comments.text: I agree with the guy from the video. GREAT TABLET!!! Just got it a couple of days ago and I wasn't sure it was going to be worth it. It really is﻿ an awesome tablet :D

comments.text: ﻿ I am looking for a digital writing pad that (1) can write in different colors and characters (using Windows Journal or something similar) (2) Can connect to a computer so that (a) I can project what is on the writing pad onto a screen and (b) I can store what has been written on the pad in the computer and I can e-mail the notes to others. I don't need any other programs/capability on the writing pad and I don't want to spend a fortune on a Motion tablet.

comments.text: (1) OneNote is perfect. (2) is a computer, (a) HDMI out (b) OneNote is perfect. Look at this ASUS, Fujitsu Q550 or Motion CL900. Don't want to spend﻿ a fortune, or don't want to save / make a fortune? You choose!

comments.text: After spending an hour grilling the sales kid, and using it myself,..i'm definately recommending this one...it's awesome,..and tho it's 'only 1.3 MGZ, it's really faster than﻿ that, and faster than most any tablet i've tried out there. Finally, a tablet with tru windows,...and u also get microsoft office with it!...yippee!!

comments.text: I am so glad I found this product review on here. Thank you for this very helpful review!

comments.text: i hope things like this going﻿ to be cheaper in future, because now i rather buy laptop than tablet with laptop hardware

comments.text: I own this tablet and it is amazing!﻿ Very fast, pretty light and great at multi tasking. Be aware of the battery life and the sd card reader can tend to break.
comments.author: KuangSteak

comments.text: How hot does it get? I own a TabletKiosk tablet﻿ PC and that thing became unusable (in-hand) because it got so hot.  After buying an iPad, I'm considering returning to tablet PC for all the reasons you state, but they are useless if they burn your hands after 1 hour of use.
comments.author: mambonova

comments.text: It has a very wide cooling vent area on the back at﻿ the top. Cools pretty well from my experience, but you should probably check tablet PC forums for the word from regular users.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text:
If you need a tablet, then you should consider the price, but buy the one that meets your needs. 

Cheap is relative to the value of something. If you don't really need it much (ie. like an iPad) then it has to be cheap for you to buy it. I'm not suggesting that this tablet﻿ is for you (from your comment I would suggest that you probably have no need for it), but just pointing out that price is not as important as you might think...
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: if u continue watching movie how long will the battery last? can u suggest me between Fujitsu Stylistic Q550 and EP121 or some other tablet that run window os...im a guy that love to watch movie on computer so i need a window tablet (this is my 1st time buy tablet) and i always travel out so i nid﻿ a long lasting tablet or something like that ...

How true it is that without Microsoft, Apple wouldn't even be around today!﻿ Furthermore, Apple WAS NOT the inventor of the icon & mouse graphical user interface that is in existence now; in fact it was Xerox that developed that technology!!!

Don't get me wrong -i do understand that Apple does make truly amazing looking products. However, I am a devout PC user and know that if it can be done with Apple, then it can be done with a PC also -THEY ARE BOTH COMPUTERS!!!

comments.text:
Using mine right now! :)
Personally I use it to sketch roughs for work in PS CS4 so I kinda feel like the side market for this tablet, the artist.  It even runs zBrush very well but it's no desktop or Cintiq just a pretty powerful slate computer.  
Just want to point out you really need to turn down the win 7 features and power save modes and screen brightness if you want to last past the 3 hr mark﻿ on the battery.

comments.text:
I bought it, installed windows 8 developers preview with USB and went the installation completely in touch, everything is  supported except bluetooth (install driver seperately).

I notice in windows8, there is improvement in the 3d acceleration.

The virtual keyboard is the best i've ever typed﻿ on. It's so responsive and has a nice muffle tapping sound. I can type very fast because of the new layout.

comments.text:
@oztabletpc
1.Is there a way to run android technology and windows 7?
2. Is there a program to transform the﻿ handwriting into computer text/
3 Which keyboard do you recommend?
comments.author: liwaroman

comments.text: is there an﻿ external battery for more battery life that you can buy?
comments.author: Ykhavari

comments.text:
Not on this one. If you need a longer battery life check out some alternatives like the Samsung Series 7 Slate (Home / Executive use -﻿ 4.5 - 5 hours) or the Motion Computing J3500 and F5v (Rugged field use, hot swappable batteries). 

Functionally these tablets are all identical. The difference is in the form factor.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text:
Is the stylus pen included on the ASUS Prime and can﻿ you do a comparison of the two? 

Please and thank you
comments.author: liwaroman

comments.text: No, Wacom﻿ Active Digitizer pens only appear on Windows tablets currently. Whilst I have an Android phone, I'm not particularly interested in iPads and Tabs etc as these tend to be more entertainment devices rather than productivity tools at this stage.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text:
So the ASUS prime can not run﻿ windows 7?  If I buy the Wacom Active Digitizer pen will it work on the ASUS Prime or is the software strictly for Windows tablets? And if that is not not possible which tablet would you recommend that is a little smaller about 10 inches but still works with a Wacom Active Digitizer pen. 

Thank You
comments.author: liwaroman

comments.text:
ASUS Prime is an Android Tablet. It cannot run Windows. The Wacom Active Digitizer is both a pen and a digitizer panel that must be built into the device, so it cannot be used on just any tablet. It's not a software issue, however many Windows  Tablet PCs like the ASUS EP121 do have the Wacom Active Digitizer built in.

As you can see in the video, Windows﻿ has lots of other software goodies for tablets with Active Digitizers too like handwriting recognition.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: The Samsung Series 7 Slate is an 11" tablet with the﻿ Wacom pen. If you're after something smaller, that would be where i'd go...
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: I'm a lecturer. I am looking for a tablet﻿ PC that will help me in presenting my lectures so that I can make notes while presenting. At the moment I have to use a separate whiteboard. Would this be a good tablet PC to get? Should I wait for the next model?
comments.author: jolandilab

comments.text: This tablet would do fine. Many lecturers are already using Windows 7 tablets to replace whiteboards and overhead projectors. Of course if you wait﻿ for the next model, there will be another one knocking on the door!
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: @oztabletpc Would you﻿ recomended the ASUS Ep121 or Samsung Slate 7?
comments.author: mawny9

comments.text:
Depends a lot on you and what you want a tablet to do... Samsung S7S is smaller and lighter with better battery life. It also has a "Sandy Bridge" Intel Core i5 which is newer than the Asus.

On the other hand the Asus has a bigger screen and much better colour reproduction. A number of my customers have also perceived it﻿ to be quicker than the Samsung although technically it shouldn't be. 

Tell me more about what's important to you and I can advise you better,
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: I'll be using the tablet to annote lecture slides/tutorails at uni, have interactive presentation capabilities, send emails and do some image editing. The fact I can have access to the entire office suite is also one of the main reasons why I'm shying away from an android based﻿ tablet. Thanks for your insight. Great videos.
comments.author: mawny9

comments.text: So I basically want it to use at uni﻿ for annotating slides, having interactive presentation capabilities and completing some image editing. Both models are around the same price tag so don't know which way to go.
comments.author: mawny9

comments.text: Both will do fine, but I would lean towards the Samsung for better battery life and smaller size. Be sure﻿ to get the Samsung Stand Case also.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: This﻿ will probably sound really stupid but; can you run Minecraft on this aswell as aal other programs and games?

comments.text: Yes, It's a PC..﻿
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text:
ok what about comparing﻿ the asus ep121 with motion computing j3500?
pros and cons?
comments.author: candyqueen5480

comments.text: J3500 has removable batteries,﻿ better battery life, vehicle and desktop docking options and the Gorilla Glass version is better outside. It's heavier though, but rugged. That's the quick comparison...
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: Thanks﻿ =)

comments.text: This tablet PC is the computer's industry's version of the series "Firefly". It's brilliant, superior to the competition, but poorly marketed. I just hope it doesn't meet the same end one day, and Apple/Android﻿ zombies don't take over the world.

comments.text: Excellent video! Have liked and subscribed. Got one﻿ quick question for you though, is it possible to remotely control my desktop computer with it. If so, what software should I install?
comments.author: kamuskaizen

comments.text: Yes remote desktop works very easily with an active digitizer pen like the one on the EP121. In terms of software the﻿ two packages that I use every day are Microsoft Office and Bluebeam Revu.

Did I hear it correctly: 3 or 4 hours batterylife?
Does﻿ it have a simcardslot?

comments.text: Correct on battery life. No 3G for this tablet though. Try the Samsung Series﻿ 7 Slate.

comments.text: get﻿ video! But had one question... Does it have windows word or something like it, on the slate?

comments.text: Microsoft Office is pre-installed on the tablet as a﻿ 60 day trial. All versions off office include Microsoft Word. Purchase a product key to activate and keep using it past the 60 day trial.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: only 2-3﻿ hours!?

comments.text: Yes, not great battery life on this one. This years windows tablets (the good ones with an Intel Core i5) will get﻿ up to 6 to 10 hours, but with 2 hour charge times (not 5 like ipad).

comments.text:
Oh wow, thats great, can you refrence﻿ me any models Oz?  When are they supposed to come out?

Also if you know, do they have one that doubles as a laptop form?   some of these little rinky dink docking things scare me.  if there was some crazy super stable fold able laptop thing that would easilly compare to my current laptop, and then if i want to use the tablet itself i can just slide it out.  Sorry if its a dumb question ha. Thanks.

Always wanted "The artists" portable pc.

comments.text: Fujitsu Q702, Samsung Series 7﻿ Slate (ATIV), both with very nice, strong detachable keyboard docks.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: ipad has 10 hour battery life, lol, or﻿ more
comments.author: Sonickart

comments.text: Great! 10 hours of not doing much plus 5 hours to charge. I guess it all depends on how you value your time. The new Fujitsu Q702 can go 10 hours as﻿ can many oter newer Windows tablets running real productivity software, not poor excuses.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: i don't even understand why compare them.﻿ apple has macbooks with macOS to compare with windows. It's so sad how you people have to compare the obvious superior operating system windows, with iOS, what started off as a mobile phone OS, to now a tablet, in order to belittle it. how sad.
comments.author: Sonickart

comments.text:
It's got nothing to do with belittling iOS and it's not an emotional thing. This is simply about helping people to understand the difference. Many people still don't even know that tablets other than iPad exist, let alone what they are﻿ good for. That's why we make these videos to inform.

There's nothing wrong with playing games and doing simple tasks on an iPad, but if you need more there is a good alternaive.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: and i completely agree. the ipad's capacitive touch screen renders a huge variety of tasks useless due to the lack of precision with a stylus.﻿ The ipad's hardware and capabilities are built more for entertainment rather than productivity, although a lot of apps allow you do some productive things. yes it's a good way to show people that there's different choices probably better suited for their needs than an ipad, but it's insulting that you didn't mention a single positive thing about the ipad
comments.author: Sonickart

comments.text: actually, you should've compared it to a jailbroken ipad 3. not ipad 1 or 2 whatever that was. i can use a usb drive on it. of﻿ course it's only for tech-literate people but whatever. and let me tell you, not much to not value about sleeping AND charging the ipad through the night, don't know if you thought about that. i'm not saying ipad is better. to each their own, and i love windows, and i recognize each and every flaw of each OS, i just think comparing a mobile OS to a pc OS is unfair.
comments.author: Sonickart

comments.text: and to wrap it up. my ipad fits all my needs. email, word processing, checking school things, and even file management since i'm no noob. yes of course windows is﻿ SO much more versatile, but it does a little more than i need it to do for school, so i thought 10 hours of doing exactly what i need, beats 3-4 hours of endless possibilities that i won't bother getting to. ipads aren't bad at all when youre tech-literate.
comments.author: Sonickart

comments.text:
Mate, Apple is the largest tech company in the world now with millions of people fawning over it's un-innovative, iterative product releases every year. It doesn't need any help. 

And really, once you've used a windows Tablet like the Samsung Series 7 Slate, you'll never go back. If you want the simpleton experience of an iPad like touch interface﻿ then Windows 8 gives you the best of both worlds too.

And the trouble with your charging theory is that whenever I go to pick up the iPad it's flat.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: not sure what you mean by flat and what's the downside to charging it overnight, plus i've never wasted even half its battery during a whole day's use. Anyway, I know windows is better, that's a little too obvious to point out. But that's what i got﻿ laptops for.
comments.author: Sonickart

comments.text:
What I mean by flat is "is not charged." Because we rarely use the iPad (since it has limited function) the last person to use it never puts it on charge and it's always flat. Plus iPad has such a﻿ slooow charge time! 

Unfortunately as I've said many times before, it may be obvious to you, but it is not obvious to the majority of people. If we didn't get asked, "what's the difference between this and an iPad" every day we wouldn't have to make the video. The differnce is quite obvious to me...
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: I really need to know this. Does this have a traditional hard drive like a regular laptop? Reason I ask is because I use PowerIso to mount cds and would﻿ need a drive to mount it. Can anyone answer my question?
comments.author: 00SoldierofFortune00

comments.text: It has a 64Gb SSD and like all PCs it shows in the system as a C:\ drive... Is that what you mean? I use﻿ Daemon Tools to mount virtual DVD/CDs. Works perfectly.
comments.author: oztabletpc

comments.text: I actually meant a disk drive (my mistake), but I know this doesnt have a disk drive,﻿ so I would just have to use a flash drive to act as an external harddrive to mount cds and other things.
comments.author: 00SoldierofFortune00

comments.text: Yes, it has a disk drive, just like﻿ a laptop PC. It is a laptop and i t runs a full version of Windows.
